title: Worcester cathedral is blasted for 'infantile pantomime'
title_page: Worcester cathedral is blasted for 'infantile pantomime' | Daily Mail Online
text:
Religious groups have been left outraged by a thanksgiving service blessing asparagus - calling it an 'absurd pantomime-type scene making a mockery of Christian worship'.
An annual festival celebrating the vegetable in Worcester kicked off on St George's Day - traditionally the start of the English Asparagus Growing season.
However the service has been dubbed silly and 'an infantile pantomime' by some groups who claim it brought the Church of England into disrepute.

The British Asparagus Festival runs throughout May and early June around the Vale of Evesham - one of the biggest producers of the vegetable in the UK.
The Sunday service saw 'Gus the Asparagus Man' joining a host of other characters including St George leading a procession through Worcester Cathedral.
The crop was then blessed by the Reverend Canon Dr Michael Brierley.
But the service was criticised on the Church of England blog Archbishop Cranmer.
The blog is run by conservative academic, theologian, author and educationalist Adrian Hitlon, who is currently based at the Department of Education at the University of Oxford.
The blog asks: 'Did the Dean of Worcester Cathedral not pause to think for just one second how utterly, utterly absurd this would look?
'A sacred procession down the Cathedral nave becomes an infantile pantomime as a block of asparagus is elevated and adored like the Blessed Host, and two men dressed up like Monty Python pay some sort of vacuous obsequious homage.'

It adds: 'Would the Church of England permit a man dressed up as a baked bean to process behind a Heinz tin of the things, and sanctify the mummery with a facade of thanksgiving?
'And why only adoration of asparagus? Where’s the sprout liturgy, or equality for mushrooms? Would the Dean really permit a walking fungus to participate in an act of divine worship?'
